Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of torso and part of head of warrior stepping forward to right and looking back, wearing helmet and corselet over short tunic with dots in added red; scabbard hanging behind him to the left from an added white baldric; his shield (partly preserved) is seen in profile behind his left arm; his right arm is raised. Uncertain object top right.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Louvre F6 (near)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Akademisches Kunstmuseum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For the warrior's awkward pose (moving right, turning back with torso in back view and shield on left arm), compare Munich J581 (ABV 126.53; CVA Munich 1, 9-10, pls. 100, 101; Boardman, ABFV fig. 76); for a naked warrior in a similar pose with profile shield on his left arm, see the name vase by the Painter of the Vatican 309 (Boardman ABFV fig. 730.
Bibliographic references: Piekarski 2001 / Die Keramik aus Naukratis im Akademischen Kunstmuseum Bonn (p.40, no. C14, pl. 14, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1055)
